cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the central branches of philosophy, such as logic, theory of knowledge, metaphysics, ethics, and political philosophy. Writings from the central figures in the history of Western and non-Western philosophy, as well as contemporary philosophers, may be considered.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Philosophy (Historical)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: PHL101Y1, PHL201H1, PHLA10H3, PHLA11H3, PHL101H5, PHL102H5, PHL105Y5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Central texts of the pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, and post-Aristotelian philosophy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be live-streamed via Zoom and recorded for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials will be live-streamed via Zoom. A web camera and microphone are needed for tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to some of the post-Hegelian thinkers who inspired the various philosophical movements broadly referred to as continental, such as phenomenology, existentialism, deconstruction, and post-modernism. Questions include the will, faith, death, existence, history and politics, rationality and its limits, encountering an other. Authors studied may include: Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Marx, Freud, Heidegger, Sartre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Continental Philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to issues in the fundamental branches of philosophy: metaphysics, which considers the overall framework of reality; epistemology, or the theory of knowledge; and related problems in the philosophy of science. Topics in metaphysics may include: mind and body, causality, space and time, God, freedom and determinism; topics in epistemology may include perception, evidence, belief, truth, skepticism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Knowledge and Reality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed as per the schedule via BB Collaborate. Recordings of the lecture will be posted on Quercus for asynchronous viewing. A microphone will be required for participation in tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Consciousness and its relation to the body; personal identity and survival; knowledge of other minds; psychological events and behaviour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Persons, Minds and Bodies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Pre-recorded lectures will be posted on Tuesdays for asynchronous viewing. The Thursday meeting section will be a discussion session that is livestreamed using BB Collaborate. A microphone and camera are required for participation.

cmCourseInfo.description: Philosophical issues about sex and sexual identity in the light of biological, psychological and ethical theories of sex and gender; the concept of gender; male and female sex roles; perverse sex; sexual liberation; love and sexuality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Philosophy of Human Sexuality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to formal deductive logic. Semantics, symbolization, and techniques of natural deduction in sentential logic. Symbolization, natural deduction, and models in monadic predicate logic. Symbolization and natural deduction with polyadic predicates. Introduction to advanced concepts in first-order logic, such as operations, identity, and models.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Symbolic Logic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Justifications for the legal enforcement of morality; particular ethical issues arising out of the intersection of law and morality, such as punishment, freedom of expression and censorship, autonomy and paternalism, constitutional protection of human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Law and Morality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of environmental issues raising questions of concern to moral and political philosophers, such as property rights, responsibility for future generations, and the interaction of human beings with the rest of nature. Typical issues: sustainable development, alternative energy, the preservation of wilderness areas, animal rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting times via Zoom. Lectures will be recorded for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to central issues in ethics or moral philosophy, such as the objectivity of values, the nature of moral judgements, rights and duties, the virtues, and consequentialism. Readings may be drawn from a variety of contemporary and historical sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed as per the meeting schedule via Zoom. Lecture recordings will be posted on Quercus for asynchronous viewing. Tutorials will be held as per the meeting schedule and will require a microphone and camera for participation.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the study of moral and legal problems in medical practice and in biomedical research; the development of health policy. Topics include: concepts of health and disease, patient rights, informed consent, allocation of scarce resources, euthanasia, abortion, genetic and reproductive technologies, human research, and mental health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Selected metaphysical, epistemological, and ethical themes in Plato’s dialogues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Plato
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL200Y1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting time via Zoom. Recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: Central philosophical problems arising in the early modern period.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in 17th and 18th Century Philosophy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL210Y1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be live-streamed on Zoom. Recordings will be posted online for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: German and French philosophy after World War II, focusing on such topics as: debates about humanism, hermeneutics, critical theory, the structuralist movement, its successors such as deconstruction. Typical authors: Heidegger, Gadamer, Habermas, Levi-Strauss, Foucault, Derrida.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Continental Philosophy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL217H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

cmCourseInfo.description: Typical issues include: the mind-brain identity theory; intentionality and the mental; personal identity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Issues in Philosophy of Mind
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One of COG250Y1/PHL240H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Pre-recorded lecture videos will be posted at the beginning of each week for asynchronous viewing. The scheduled class time will be used for discussion sessions and office hours via Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level study of selected issues in moral philosophy, or of influential contemporary or historical works in ethical theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL275H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be livestreamed via Zoom as per the schedule and recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing. Students will require a microphone in order to participate in discussions.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intermediate-level study of moral and legal problems, including the philosophical significance of death, the high-tech prolongation of life, definition and determination of death, suicide, active and passive euthanasia, the withholding of treatment, palliative care and the control of pain, living wills; recent judicial decisions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics: Death and Dying
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PHL281H1, 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. The instructor will post a 2-hour pre-recorded lecture each week. 1-hour of the scheduled time will be used for a live-streamed lecture which will be recorded for asynchronous viewing. The remaining 2-hours will be used for an optional discussion session and office hours. A microphone and webcam is preferred for the fullest learning experience.

cmCourseInfo.description: The literary expression of philosophical ideas and the interplay between literature and philosophy. Such philosophical issues as the nature and origin of good and evil in human beings, the nature and extent of human freedom and responsibility, and the diverse forms of linguistic expression. Such authors as Wordsworth, Mill, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Miller, Camus, and Lawrence are studied.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Philosophy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 7.5 courses (in any field) with at least 1.5 in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be live-streamed at the scheduled meeting times via BB Collaborate. Lectures will also be recorded for asynchronous viewing. A camera and microphone is recommended for those who wish to participate during synchronous lectures.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of key philosophical works published within the last five years.
cmCourseInfo.title: New Books Seminar

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Students will need internet access and a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online sections.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Feb 26, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of some area or problem in the philosophy of science.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Philosophy of Science
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One of PHL355H1, PHL357H1 or HPS250H1, 4.0 credits in philosophy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online-synchronous course. Lectures will be livestreamed via Zoom at the scheduled meeting times. A microphone and camera are required for participation.

cmCourseInfo.description: Individual Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Individual Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For 'E' indicator courses: students can download Independent Study forms off the Philosophy Department website: https://philosophy.utoronto.ca/st-george/undergraduate-at-st-george/courses/individual-studies-courses/. All forms must be received at Jackman Humanities Building, 170 St. George Street, Room 403 or by email to eric.correia@utoronto.ca, no later than the first week of classes.
